Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the way we handle anhydrous ammonia, the safety devices inherent in the design of the facility, combined with the safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel.

Plum Point Energy Station (PPES) emergency response program (SMP-02 Rev 8 dated June 2023) is designed to effectively respond to an accidental release of ammonia. The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially effected neighbors.

Corporate Safety Policy:

Safety is a core value of PPES, and it is the policy of this Company to provide its employees, visitors, and
contractors with a safe and healthy site of employment.

The acceptable standard of performance in safety matters is to promote safe work practices, achieve zero accidents or injuries in all aspects of our operations, and fully comply with all applicable rules, regulations, laws, contractual requirements and "best practices." Additionally, we will continually seek opportunities to improve safety including an aggressive "Lessons Learned" process and will provide all applicable information to our employees and customers.

In achieving this objective, all PPES organizations, divisions, and subsidiaries develop, implement, and ensure compliance with effective safety procedures as applicable to their specific environment. In these actions, the Company will continue to emphasize that each employee is responsible for his or her own safety, the safety of fellow employees, and the safety of the public.

Employees are expected to be mentally alert and work safely as a condition of employment. Employees shall adhere to all safety warnings and posted safety signs whenever they are on company property. PPES shall meet all applicable regulations and provide accurate and timely safety monito

ring and reporting. The Company will be responsive to the safety concerns of our employees, communities, and the public.

Contractors are expected to adhere to all PPES rules and procedures in addition to their own rules and
procedures plus any local, state, and federal regulations pertinent to their work. Whenever there are
differences in work rules, it is expected that the rule resulting in the greatest safety to employees and the public will be followed. Deviations from PPES rules and procedures shall be discussed in advance with PPES management.

PPES will audit and monitor our compliance with all applicable laws, permits, agreements, and the objectives of this policy. We will take appropriate action to correct noted deficient areas, keep accurate and complete information, and make regular reports to PPES Management.

This Policy is disseminated to each of our employees, contractors, and customers.

Facility Description and Regulated Substances:

The Plum Point Energy Station consists of one (1) pulverized coal-fired boiler. The facility has a gross
output of 723.3 MW, with a net output of 665 MW. The boiler utilizes Low NOx burners and overfire air in conjunction with a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) module for NOx control. Anhydrous Ammonia, as a vapor is injected into the SCR module for conversion of the NOx emissions into nitrogen and water.

Additional emission control equipment associated with the pulverized coal-fired boiler include baghouse for particulate control, activated carbon injection for mercury control, and a Spray Dryer Absorber / Dry Flue Gas Desulfurization unit for SO2 control. The Spray Dryer Absorber operation utilizes calcium hydroxide for SO2 removal.

The facility also operates a 285 MMBtu/hr #2 fuel oil fired Auxiliary Boiler used to assist with startup of the coal-fired boiler and emergency operations. The Auxiliary Boiler is limited to 500 hours of operations per years. The Auxiliary Boiler does not utilize any RMP/PSM regulated

substances in its operation.

Anhydrous Ammonia (CAS# 7664-41-7) is used to control Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) emissions and stored in above the Threshold Quantity of 10,000 lbs.

Anhydrous ammonia (Regulated Substance) will be used as the NOx reduction reagent. A 12,750-gallon
working capacity anhydrous ammonia storage tank has been constructed at the site. Additional project
components include a power distribution center, continuous emission monitoring system, fuel handling and ash processing systems.

Accidental Release Prevention and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:

PPES is committed to public safety, personnel safety, continued reliable operation, and regulatory compliance. 

Based on this commitment, the Plant Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the RMP. A management system has been developed with clearly defined accountability and responsibility for the Risk Management Program.

To help ensure that a worst-case or alternative release scenario does not occur, PPES maintains a release prevention program with the primary focus of protecting the public and plant employees from the hazards associated with an accident or release involving anhydrous ammonia. The multifaceted program includes the use of:

?	Ammonia gas detectors and alarms to rapidly alert operators to any problems;
?	A deluge system to mitigate impacts of any ammonia release;
?	Process Safety Information to document the safe process design;
?	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) to evaluate the chemical and process hazards;
?	Operating Procedures to ensure that the system is operated safely,
?	Maintenance, Inspection, and Testing to ensure that the system is properly maintained;
?	Safe Work Practices to ensure that employees working on and around the processes are aware of the hazards, can perform their job duties safely, and know the actions to be taken in an emergency.
?	Incident Investigation procedure to investigate incidents and "near misses" to determine root

causes and make needed safety improvements; and,
?	Compliance Audits to periodically verify that our programs are working as they should.

Five Year Accident History:

Plum Point has not had any accidents associated with the Anhydrous Ammonia regulated substance in the previous 5 years.

Emergency Response Program:

If an anhydrous ammonia release does occur, PPES has an emergency response program (SMP-02 Rev 8 dated June 2023) that coordinates emergency response with the Osceola Fire Department (OFD). Additionally, the plant has emergency operations procedures in place detailing appropriate emergency actions to help mitigate the effects of any release.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

PPES site personal are trained annually on safe operation and use of the Anhydrous Ammonia System.
